subject: Re: [junit] Best practices [Topic]
msgSnippet: I think if we follow a basic rule that we append and do not over write previous comments this will be an excellent tool. I agree with Vladimir, let s give it a
messageBody:
I think if we follow a basic rule that we append and do not over
write previous comments this will be an excellent tool.

I agree with Vladimir, let's give it a try.

In the first phase of this project we should encourage people to
enter thoughtful comments.

Once a topic has a sufficient number of comments, and a general
consensus has been reached, the information should be rewritten with
specific code examples. I�ll volunteer to do some (or most) of the
rewriting, with Vladimir acting as the final editor. We can save the
original comments page as a background link for the summary page.

If we base the examples on the sample code shipped with JUnit, we
should be able to expand these �Best Practices� topics into a very
useful tutorial for new users.

Many thanks to J. B. Rainsberger for taking the time to put this
together.

Mike

PS to J. B. Rainsberger. I�ve communicated with you on other issues.
I think you could make a valued contribution in helping to rewrite
the summaries.


--- Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...> wrote:
> > Is it possible for people to just submit request, so that we
> won't overwrite
> > each other's change? I can see that this will become a hot topic
> and there
> > will be cases that several people changing it at the same time.
>
> and people with different point of views trying to expose "or
> impose" their ideas. I think it's a great tool and hope that
> people will be responsible and not screw up everything.
>
> So let's give it a try and see the result in a couple of weeks.
>
> -Vladimir
>
>
>
